name: title_plot
system_prompt:
You are an assistant tasked with comparing three lists of movies. For each movie, you are given its: title, plot
Your main goal is to assign a diversity score to each list based on the given information.
Use your own judgment to determine what information is relevant when assessing the diversity of the lists. 
You should consider the given title, plot for every movie.

Deliver your descriptions of lists, comparison and choice of the most diverse list in the following JSON format:

{
    "list_A_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list A
    "list_B_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list B
    "list_C_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list C
    "comparison": string,                      # Compare the diversity of the lists.
    "diversity_scores": dict                   # A dictionary assigning a diversity score (0-10) to each list based on its relative diversity. Example: {"A": 5, "B": 2, "C": 10} (where C is the most diverse and B the least).
}

evaluations.prompt:
List A:
TITLE: Big Hero 6 (2014)
PLOT: A special bond develops between plus-sized inflatable robot Baymax and prodigy Hiro Hamada, who together team up with a group of friends to form a band of high-tech heroes.

TITLE: Others, The (2001)
PLOT: In 1945, immediately following the end of Second World War, a woman who lives with her two photosensitive children on her darkened old family estate in the Channel Islands becomes convinced that the home is haunted.

TITLE: Catch Me If You Can (2002)
PLOT: Barely 21 yet, Frank is a skilled forger who has passed as a doctor, lawyer and pilot. FBI agent Carl becomes obsessed with tracking down the con man, who only revels in the pursuit.

TITLE: Meet the Parents (2000)
PLOT: Male nurse Greg Focker meets his girlfriend's parents before proposing, but her suspicious father is every date's worst nightmare.

TITLE: Whiplash (2014)
PLOT: A promising young drummer enrolls at a cut-throat music conservatory where his dreams of greatness are mentored by an instructor who will stop at nothing to realize a student's potential.

TITLE: Super Size Me (2004)
PLOT: While examining the influence of the fast food industry, Morgan Spurlock personally explores the consequences on his health of a diet of solely McDonald's food for one month.

TITLE: Patriot, The (2000)
PLOT: Peaceful farmer Benjamin Martin is driven to lead the Colonial Militia during the American Revolution when a sadistic British officer murders his son.

TITLE: Office Space (1999)
PLOT: Three company workers who hate their jobs decide to rebel against their greedy boss.

PLOT: When Jason Bourne is framed for a CIA operation gone awry, he is forced to resume his former life as a trained assassin to survive.

PLOT: The Guardians struggle to keep together as a team while dealing with their personal family issues, notably Star-Lord's encounter with his father, the ambitious celestial being Ego.

TITLE: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)
PLOT: A soldier fighting aliens gets to relive the same day over and over again, the day restarting every time he dies.

TITLE: Iron Man (2008)
PLOT: After being held captive in an Afghan cave, billionaire engineer Tony Stark creates a unique weaponized suit of armor to fight evil.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a broad range of genres and themes. It includes animation (Big Hero 6), psychological thriller (The Others), biographical crime (Catch Me If You Can), romantic comedy (Meet the Parents), drama (Whiplash), documentary (Super Size Me), historical drama (The Patriot), and workplace comedy (Office Space).  The time periods and settings are also diverse, spanning from the American Revolution to modern-day settings.
response.list_B_description: List B is more focused on action and thriller genres, with several films featuring espionage (Bourne Identity, Bourne Supremacy), superhero elements (Guardians of the Galaxy 2, Iron Man, Batman Begins), and science fiction (Edge of Tomorrow). While it includes some overlap with List A (The Others, Catch Me If You Can), the overall thematic and genre diversity is less pronounced.
response.list_C_description: List C is almost identical to List B, sharing the same focus on action, thriller, and superhero genres. The only difference is the absence of one movie from List B, which does not significantly alter the overall lack of diversity in genres and themes.
response.comparison: List A exhibits significantly greater diversity than Lists B and C. Lists B and C are nearly identical and heavily concentrated in action, thriller, and superhero genres with minimal variation in themes or settings. List A, in contrast, showcases a wider array of genres, tones, and historical periods, resulting in a richer and more diverse collection of films.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety in genre and theme. It includes a post-apocalyptic thriller (I Am Legend), an animated adventure (Zootopia), a biographical drama (A Beautiful Mind), a romantic comedy (Midnight in Paris), a drama about family relationships (Rain Man), a comedy (School of Rock), a historical war drama (The Patriot), and an office comedy (Office Space).  The settings and time periods are also diverse.
response.list_B_description: List B has a more focused selection of films. While it still offers genre variety (superhero, thriller, drama, horror, comedy), there's a noticeable concentration on character studies and narratives with a darker or more intense tone.  Several films share similar themes of family relationships or personal struggles. The time periods are more concentrated than List A.
response.list_C_description: List C boasts the most diverse range of movies. It includes animation (Big Hero 6), a mystery (Journal 64), a documentary (The Haunted World of Edward D. Wood Jr.), a romantic drama (Dirty Dancing), a historical war drama (The Tuskegee Airmen), a mockumentary (7 Days in Hell), a Western (Django Unchained), and a science fiction action film (Tokyo Tribe). The genres, settings, and time periods are very diverse.
response.comparison: List C stands out as the most diverse, showcasing a wide array of genres, tones, and settings. List A offers a good level of diversity, while List B, although varied in genre, presents a more homogenous selection in terms of themes and overall tone.

response.list_A_description: List A shows some diversity in genre and setting, ranging from war dramas (Saving Private Ryan) to romantic comedies (Tanu Weds Manu), and including a variety of other genres such as crime (SuperFly), historical fiction (Aferim!, The Miniaturist), and animation (Open Season). However, there's a noticeable concentration on films from different countries and cultures, which adds to its diversity.
response.list_B_description: List B is less diverse than List A. While it includes some variety in genre (action, drama, comedy), the settings and themes are less varied.  Many of the films seem to focus on family or relationships, with a few exceptions. The overall tone is less diverse than List A.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a good mix of genres, including action (Mr. & Mrs. Smith, Pirates of the Caribbean), crime (Goodfellas), science fiction (Rogue One, Ex Machina), animation (Monsters, Inc., Up), and war (Saving Private Ryan). The settings and themes are also more varied than List B, making it more diverse.
response.comparison: List C exhibits the greatest diversity, encompassing a wide range of genres, settings, and themes. List A shows a decent level of diversity, particularly in its representation of different cultures and countries. List B is the least diverse, with a narrower focus on themes and settings.

response.list_C_description: List C exhibits more diversity than Lists A and B. response.comparison: List C is the most diverse, offering a wider range of genres and themes compared to Lists A and B. Lists A and B are very similar and lack the thematic breadth of List C. While Lists A and B have a good variety, they are somewhat dominated by fantasy and superhero elements.

response.comparison: List A exhibits the highest degree of diversity due to its wider range of genres and styles compared to List B and List C. List B is less diverse, primarily focusing on action and science fiction. List C shows a decent variety but lacks the breadth of List A.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a moderate diversity of genres and themes. It includes science fiction (Source Code, Monsters Inc.), action (Django Unchained, Kill Bill), comedy (Hangover), drama (Intouchables, Terminal), and a blend of action and science fiction (Rogue One). response.list_B_description: List B has a similar level of genre diversity to List A, but with a stronger emphasis on crime and drama.  It includes science fiction (Source Code), animation (Monsters Inc.), crime (Goodfellas), comedy (Hangover), drama (American Beauty, Terminal), and action-comedy (Tropic Thunder). The inclusion of Goodfellas and American Beauty shifts the thematic focus towards crime and character studies.
response.list_C_description: List C demonstrates the highest level of diversity. It encompasses historical epics (Gladiator), drama (Intouchables), animation (Monsters Inc.), science fiction (Source Code, Rogue One), superhero (Deadpool), adventure (Life of Pi), and Western (Django Unchained). The settings, themes, and tones are more varied than in Lists A and B, offering a broader range of cinematic experiences.
response.comparison: List C stands out as the most diverse, showcasing a wider range of genres, tones, and thematic elements compared to Lists A and B. Lists A and B share several movies and exhibit a more concentrated focus on specific genres, such as action and crime, respectively.  List C's inclusion of diverse genres like historical epics, animation, and adventure significantly enhances its diversity score.

PLOT: The story of King George VI, his unexpected ascension to the throne of the British Empire in 1936, and the speech therapist who helped the unsure monarch overcome his stammer.

TITLE: Untitled Spider-Man Reboot (2017)
PLOT: Peter Parker balances his life as an ordinary high school student in Queens with his superhero alter-ego Spider-Man, and finds himself on the trail of a new menace prowling the skies of New York City.

TITLE: Lucy (2014)
PLOT: A woman, accidentally caught in a dark deal, turns the tables on her captors and transforms into a merciless warrior evolved beyond human logic.

TITLE: Others, The (2001)
PLOT: In 1945, immediately following the end of Second World War, a woman who lives with her two photosensitive children on her darkened old family estate in the Channel Islands becomes convinced that the home is haunted.

TITLE: Fast and the Furious, The (2001)
PLOT: Los Angeles police officer Brian O'Conner must decide where his loyalty really lies when he becomes enamored with the street racing world he has been sent undercover to destroy.

TITLE: Donnie Brasco (1997)
PLOT: An FBI undercover agent infiltrates the mob and finds himself identifying more with the Mafia life--at the expense of his regular one.

TITLE: Serenity (2005)
PLOT: The crew of the ship Serenity try to evade an assassin sent to recapture telepath River.

TITLE: Moonrise Kingdom (2012)
PLOT: A pair of young lovers flee their New England town, which causes a local search party to fan out to find them.


List B:
TITLE: King's Speech, The (2010)
PLOT: The story of King George VI, his unexpected ascension to the throne of the British Empire in 1936, and the speech therapist who helped the unsure monarch overcome his stammer.

TITLE: Trailer Park Boys: Say Goodnight to the Bad Guys (2008)
PLOT: It has been one year since the boys have become rich. Julian decided to keep the money safe, but when it comes time for everyone to get their share, the money is lost forever.

TITLE: Into the Dark: Pure (2019)
PLOT: Several teenage girls at a Purity Retreat participate in a secret ritual, and they start to see a supernatural entity. The girls need to focus on the demon they have unleashed, as well as their fathers' expectations.

TITLE: Titanic 2 (2010)
PLOT: A century after the fateful voyage of the original, modern luxury liner Titanic II sets sail. Will this ship suffer the same fate as her namesake?

TITLE: Beethoven's 3rd (2000)
PLOT: The Newton family from the first two Beethoven movies is on vacation in Europe, but they do plan to attend a Newton family reunion, and to make sure one of their family members definitely makes it, they ship him to travel to there with George's brother, Richard. Guess which one it was? That's right, Beethoven. He follows Richard and his family as they hit the road to California in a huge, shiny, and expensive RV, equipped with a DVD player. Following them are two bumbling crooks who have hidden some secret codes on a DVD that they figure no one in the world will buy, but someone does: Richard. So now they have a DVD holding top secret information, and the crooks must get it back.â€”Dylan Self <robocoptng986127@aol.com>

TITLE: Titanica (1992)
PLOT: Titanica reveals the clearest motion pictures ever captured of the Titanic. Witness startling images of the long-lost ruin contrasted with never-before-seen 1912 archival photos showing her in all her splendor. Feel the passion of the explorers, each obsessed with a different aspect of the expedition.â€”Anonymous

TITLE: Hellphone (2007)
PLOT: A teen-ager feels an endless fascination for his cellular phone which will enable him to reach his aim: alluring the pretty high-school girl he's in love with. Unfortunately, this addiction will not be without negative consequences on the behavior of the boy.â€”Anonymous

TITLE: Goldman v Silverman (2020)
PLOT: Rod Goldman and Al Silverman are street performers who work the tourist scene of Times Square. Goldman gets no respect and Silverman is the first one to make sure of that.


List C:
TITLE: King's Speech, The (2010)
PLOT: The story of King George VI, his unexpected ascension to the throne of the British Empire in 1936, and the speech therapist who helped the unsure monarch overcome his stammer.

TITLE: Bongwater (1997)
PLOT: An indolent artist in Portland, Oregon becomes addicted to marijuana, prompting his girlfriend to flee to New York City with a heroin addict.

TITLE: I Trapped The Devil (2019)
PLOT: A man descends into paranoia after trapping what he believes to be the devil in his basement, but things take a dark turn when his family unexpectedly arrive for Christmas.

TITLE: Kizumonogatari II: Passionate Blood (2016)
PLOT: In the spring of his second year of high school, Koyomi Araragi met the beautiful vampire Kiss-shot Acerola-orion Heart-under-blade. Koyomi saved Kiss-shot, who was on the verge of death with all four of her limbs cut off, but only at the expense of becoming her minion and a vampire. "In order to go back to being a human again, you must take back all of Kiss-shot's limbs." After receiving advice from Meme Oshino, an expert in the supernatural, Koyomi prepares to go into battle. Awaiting him are three powerful vampire hunters-Dramaturgy, a giant vampire hunter who is a vampire himself. Episode, a half-vampire who wields an enormous cross, and Guillotinecutter, a quiet man who specializes in killing vampires. Will Koyomi be able to take back Kiss-shot's limbs from the vampire hunters? Amidst the soft spring rain, the curtain rises on this fateful blood bath.

TITLE: Take the L (2017)
PLOT: A day in the life of two best friends, a drug dealer, and a store manager collide at a hip-hop concert in the Inland Empire.

TITLE: Bilal: A New Breed of Hero (2018)
PLOT: A thousand years ago, one boy with a dream of becoming a great warrior is abducted with his sister and taken to a land far away from home. Thrown into a world where greed and injustice rule all, Bilal finds the courage to raise his voice and make a change. Inspired by true events, this is a story of a real hero who earned his remembrance in time and history.

TITLE: Nuestros amantes (2016)
PLOT: One man, one woman, one rule: don't fall in love.

TITLE: The Man Who Was Too Free (2017)
PLOT: A documentary biopic of Boris Nemtsov, a prominent figure of Russian political opposition and an outspoken critic of Vladimir Putin. Boris Nemtsov got murdered in Moscow in February of 2015.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety in genres and settings. It includes historical drama (King's Speech), superhero film (Spider-Man), action (Lucy, Fast and the Furious), thriller (The Others, Donnie Brasco), science fiction (Serenity), and coming-of-age (Moonrise Kingdom).  However, there's a slight overrepresentation of films set in the US or involving American characters.
response.list_B_description: List B is less diverse than List A. It features a mix of genres, including historical drama (King's Speech), comedy (Trailer Park Boys), horror (Into the Dark: Pure), disaster (Titanic 2), family (Beethoven's 3rd), documentary (Titanica), teen drama (Hellphone), and comedy (Goldman v Silverman). However, the plots are less sophisticated and the overall thematic range is narrower.
response.list_C_description: List C demonstrates a greater diversity of genres and cultural backgrounds compared to Lists A and B. It includes historical drama (King's Speech), drama (Bongwater), horror (I Trapped the Devil), anime (Kizumonogatari II), drama (Take the L), animated (Bilal), romance (Nuestros amantes), and documentary (The Man Who Was Too Free). The settings and themes are more varied, showcasing different cultural perspectives and storytelling styles.
response.comparison: List C stands out as the most diverse, offering a wider range of genres, cultural contexts, and narrative styles. List A presents a reasonable variety, while List B shows less diversity in both genre and thematic depth.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety of genres and themes. It includes historical drama (King's Speech), science fiction (The Philadelphia Experiment, The Terminators), horror comedy (WNUF Halloween Special), supernatural thriller (Restoration), family drama (Paa), animated musical (Barbie: A Fairy Secret), and action (Malibu Express).  However, there's a noticeable lack of thematic depth or consistency, making it feel somewhat disjointed.
response.list_B_description: List B presents a more eclectic mix. It features historical drama (King's Speech), family-friendly fantasy (The Boy Who Cried Werewolf), Russian superhero comedy (SuperBobrovs), horror (The Houses October Built), family drama (Solino), stand-up comedy (Ricky Gervais special), documentary (Honeyland), and meta-documentary (Stanley Kubrick's Boxes). The range of styles and tones is broader than List A, offering more diversity.
response.list_C_description: List C is dominated by action and superhero genres. While it includes a historical drama (King's Speech), the remaining films are largely focused on superhero adventures (Spider-Man, X-Men), science fiction action (Jurassic Park, Avatar), crime thrillers (The Departed, Lucy), and superhero family films (Incredibles). The thematic consistency limits the overall diversity.
response.comparison: List B exhibits the greatest diversity, encompassing a wider range of genres, tones, and styles than Lists A and C. List A has some variety but lacks thematic cohesion. List C is the least diverse, heavily weighted towards action and superhero narratives.

What was expected to be a brief sideline led to their becoming fully immersed in the LGBT community as they took over a local store, Circus of Books. A decade later, they had become the biggest distributors of gay porn in the US. The film focuses on the double life they led, trying to maintain the balance of being parents at a time when LGBT culture was not yet accepted. Their many challenges included facing jail time for a federal obscenity prosecution and enabling their store to be a place of refuge at the height of the AIDS crisis. Circus of Books offers a rare glimpse into an untold chapter of queer history, and it is told through the lens of the owners' own daughter, Rachel Mason, an artist, filmmaker and musician.

PLOT: A Russian and a German sniper play a game of cat-and-mouse during the Battle of Stalingrad.

TITLE: Trials of Darryl Hunt, The (2006)
PLOT: "The Trials of Darryl Hunt" is a feature documentary about a brutal rape/murder case and a wrongly convicted man, Darryl Hunt, who spent nearly twenty years in prison for a crime he did not commit. Both a social justice story and a personally driven narrative, the film chronicles this capital case from 1984 through 2004. With exclusive footage from two decades, the film frames the judicial and emotional response to a chilling crime - and the implications that reverberate from Hunt's conviction - against a backdrop of class and racial bias in the South and in the American criminal justice system. This documentary is the culmination of ten years of research and filming. In 1993, inspired by claims of injustice and police conspiracy, the filmmakers began to shoot in North Carolina. Working from a mix of formats (16mm and 24P video) the film melds the visceral reality of a murder case with first person accounts and cinematic imagery, illuminating perceptions and memories of events as they unfolded for the people closest to this haunting story. This unique look at one man's loss and redemption challenges the assumption that all Americans have the right to unbiased justice. Hunt's story - while one man's personal journey - reflects systemic issues of national concern: cross-racial eyewitness identification, prosecutorial misconduct, inexperienced defense attorneys assigned to capital cases, racial bias in death penalty cases and errors in police procedure. Barry Scheck from The Innocence Project, who worked on Hunt's case for ten years, and Gary Wells, professor and eyewitness expert, offer concrete examples where errors occurred in Hunt's saga and offer future remedies and effective ideas to prevent future "Darryl Hunts." Hunt himself addresses the need for systemic reforms to prevent wrongful convictions, underscoring the haunting reality that Hunt could have been sentenced to death and we would never have known this story.â€”Annie Sundberg

TITLE: Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru (2016)
PLOT: TONY ROBBINS: I AM NOT YOUR GURU, a feature documentary film about internationally renowned life and business strategist Tony Robbins, is a revelatory cinĂ©ma vĂ©ritĂ© film that goes behind the scenes of his mammoth seminar "Date With Destiny," attended by over 2,500 people in Boca Raton, Florida, each year, to give an insider look at how one man can affect millions. Granted never before seen access to the behind the scenes modus operandi of this enormous event, this film captures both the immense effort of producing this live seminar, as well as the life-changing transformations of the participants in real time. Embedding with Tony Robbins and his team over the course of six days, Academy Award nominated filmmaker Joe Berlinger turns an unflinching eye on Tony Robbins' powerful and uncompromising approach to achieving success, ensuring the attendees leave "Date With Destiny" with new perspective on the forces, thoughts, and feelings that motivate their behavior and help them take control of their lives. Pulling back the curtain on Tony Robbins, a man that traverses the globe and counsels over 200,000 people annually, including world leaders, pundits, entrepreneurs, CEOs, athletes and celebrities, through interviews and unprecedented access, TONY ROBBINS: I AM NOT YOUR GURU is an emotional tour de force that unveils the inner-workings of this mega event, the zealous participants and the man himself.â€”anonymous

response.comparison: List A stands out due to its inclusion of documentaries, which adds a layer of thematic depth not found in the other lists. The themes are less cohesive, jumping between horror (The Convent), historical drama (The Magic of Ordinary Days), political thriller (TerrorStorm), biographical crime (Bonnie and Clyde), and social commentary (Madaari). The inclusion of lighter fare like Operation Christmas Drop and Cavemen further disrupts any thematic consistency.
response.comparison: List A and List B are relatively similar in terms of diversity, offering a good balance of genres and themes with well-known and critically acclaimed films. List C, while attempting to showcase a wider range of genres, lacks cohesion and includes less notable films, resulting in lower overall diversity.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety in genre and theme. It includes science fiction (The Matrix), animation (Shrek 2, Aladdin), drama (Argo, Three Billboards, The Pianist, Cast Away), and musical (Pitch Perfect).  However, there's a slight overrepresentation of dramas.
response.list_B_description: List B has a mix of genres including science fiction (The Matrix), animation (Shrek 2, Aladdin), drama (Schindler's List, Cast Away), crime (The Departed), and romantic comedy (The Devil Wears Prada).  The inclusion of The Mummy Returns adds an action-adventure element. The selection is more balanced than List A but still lacks significant diversity.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a good blend of genres and styles. It features science fiction (The Matrix), animation (Shrek 2), fantasy (Lord of the Rings), animated (Toy Story), drama (Schindler's List), superhero (Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse), and crime (The Departed). The combination of animation, fantasy, drama, and superhero elements makes it the most diverse.
response.comparison: List C exhibits the most diversity, encompassing a wider range of genres and animation styles than Lists A and B. List A has a reasonable variety but leans towards drama. List B is somewhat balanced but lacks the breadth of List C.
